title: 109_hr2981
content: SECTION 1. FINDINGS AND PURPOSES. Congress finds that approximately 60 percent of Indian tribe members and Alaska Natives live on or adjacent to Indian lands with a high unemployment rate of 45 percent. These individuals own over 197,000 businesses, generating more than $34 billion in revenues. The number of businesses owned by them grew by 84 percent from 1992 to 1997, with gross receipts increasing by 179 percent during that period, outpacing the growth of all businesses in the same timeframe. The Small Business Development Center program is cost-effective, with clients generating additional tax revenues of $468 million in 1998, 6 times the program's cost to the Federal Government. Business counseling is critical on Indian lands where services are scarce. Increased assistance through counseling has been shown to reduce default rates in lending programs. The Act aims to stimulate economies on Indian lands. The Small Business Development Center program aims to stimulate economies on Indian lands by fostering economic development, assisting in creating new small businesses owned by Indian tribe members, and providing management assistance. It also seeks advice from Tribal Councils and ensures full access to business counseling for Indian tribe members, Alaska Natives, and Native Hawaiians. Small Business Development Center program provides assistance to Indian tribe members, Alaska Natives, and Native Hawaiians. The Small Business Act is amended to provide an additional grant for eligible states with a population of at least 1% Indian tribe members, Alaska Natives, and Native Hawaiians to assist with small business startups and expansions on Indian lands. The Small Business Act is amended to provide grants for eligible states with a population of at least 1% Indian tribe members, Alaska Natives, and Native Hawaiians to support small business startups and expansions on Indian lands. Grant applicants must submit detailed information including their goals, training capabilities, proposed site location, funding needs, and consultation with local Tribal Councils. The Small Business Act is amended to provide grants for eligible states with a population of at least 1% Indian tribe members, Alaska Natives, and Native Hawaiians to support small business startups and expansions on Indian lands. Grant applicants must comply with all requirements, receive a maximum of $300,000 per fiscal year, and follow regulations set by the Administration after consulting with the Association recognized by the Administration. The Small Business Act is amended to provide grants for eligible states with a population of at least 1% Indian tribe members, Alaska Natives, and Native Hawaiians to support small business startups and expansions on Indian lands. The technical and support services provided by Small Business Development Centers receiving assistance must adhere to standards set by the Administration. Definitions for terms like 'Indian lands' are also provided in this section. The curr_chunk provides definitions for terms related to Native American tribes, including 'Indian tribe,' 'Indian tribe member,' 'Alaska Native,' and 'Native Hawaiian.' These definitions are crucial for understanding the Indian Child Welfare Act of 1978. The curr_chunk defines 'Native Hawaiian' as a descendant of the aboriginal people of Hawaii pre-1778 and 'tribal organization' as per the Indian Self-Determination and Education Assistance Act. Authorization of $7,000,000 for fiscal years 2006-2008 is provided, with funding limitations specified. Funding under this paragraph is additional to program limitations specified. The Administration can only use funds appropriated in advance for this purpose. Section 21(c) of the Small Business Act is amended to require Small Business Development Centers to seek advice from tribal organizations on how to assist Indian tribe members, Alaska Natives, and Native Hawaiians.
